Power Rankings: Sharks not dead in the water just yet

by | NHL Blogger

Head coach Todd McLellan and his Sharks have time to make a run towards the top of the West. (Getty Images)  

The San Jose Sharks recently wrapped up a nine-game road trip that saw them win only two games. The trip included losses to Carolina, Tampa Bay, Columbus and Minnesota, a game that saw them blow a lead late in the third period. The trip was pretty much an on-ice disaster in almost every way imaginable.

As a result, they've dropped all the way down to the seventh spot (as of Tuesday afternoon) in the Western Conference playoff race, and are just one point ahead of the first team that is currently on the outside of the playoff picture.

But because the Pacific Division is the Western Conference's answer to the Southeast Division, where mediocrity seems to be only acceptable level of play, they're also just two points away from being back in the No. 3 seed, so it's probably a bit too early to be pushing the panic button. Especially since they still have a game in hand on the currently first-place Coyotes, as well as three more head-to-head matchups remaining. So there is still plenty of time to get back into the driver’s seat and regain control of the division. And I expect that they will do just that.

The Sharks are still getting big-time production from their top players (Joe Thornton, Patrick Marleau, Logan Couture, Dan Boyle, etc), but have needed some additional depth on their bottom two lines and have had a major hole on their penalty kill for the season -- currently sitting in the 28th spot in the NHL, ahead of only Toronto and Columbus.

Enter Monday's additions of penalty kill workhorse Daniel Winnik and T.J. Galiardi from the Colorado Avalanche.

They may not be the biggest names to switch teams ahead of the trade deadline (then again, given the list of names that did change teams, maybe they are), but they're just the type of gritty reserves that general manager Doug Wilson's team needs down the stretch.

The Sharks are still a team that dominates their opponents territorially and have outscored the opposition by 18 goals this season, the fourth best mark in the Conference. Teams like that simply don't miss the postseason, and it shouldn't be a surprise if the Sharks follow up this recent slump with a run that takes them back to the top of the Western Conference.

# **Underwater Research Station: "Shark Reef Outpost"**  

## **1. Overall Scene Theme and Core Concept**  
An aging deep-sea research station, *Shark Reef Outpost*, sits on the ocean floor near a hydrothermal vent network. The facility specializes in marine biology, deep-sea mining, and emergency salvage operations, but years of budget cuts have left it in a precarious state—much like the struggling hockey team in the inspiration text.  

The station is inherently collaborative: heavy equipment requires multiple operators, repairs demand coordinated efforts, and the ever-present threat of structural failure means that teamwork isn’t just beneficial—it’s necessary for survival.  

## **2. Spatial Layout and Area Descriptions**  
The station is a modular structure, connected by reinforced airlocks and narrow corridors. Key areas include:  

- **Main Control Room** – The nerve center, filled with flickering monitors, a sonar map of the vent field, and a leaking overhead pipe.  
- **Lab Module** – A cramped space with specimen tanks, microscopes, and half-processed mineral samples.  
- **Docking Bay** – Houses a damaged submersible, salvage crates, and a flooded repair pit.  
- **Storage & Maintenance** – Cluttered with spare parts, tool racks, and a jury-rigged oxygen recycler.  
- **Living Quarters** – Bunks, a microwave with a broken door, and a bulletin board covered in old mission logs and faded hockey game schedules (an inside joke among the crew).  

## **3. Detailed Area-by-Area Inventory**  

### **A. Main Control Room**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- Central **command console** with a cracked touchscreen, surrounded by three mismatched chairs.  
- A **sonar display table** showing the hydrothermal vent field, its surface scratched from repeated use.  
- A **leaking overhead pipe**, dripping saltwater into a makeshift bucket.  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Damaged pressure sensor** (flashing red, needs recalibration).  
- **Emergency beacon transmitter** (missing a fuse).  
- **Locked supply cabinet** (contains backup oxygen canisters—key is in the captain’s bunk).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- A **working coffee machine** (half-full pot, stale).  
- A **wall-mounted comms system** (static-filled, but operational).  
- A **rolling tool cart** (wrenches scattered, missing the 10mm socket).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- Faded **safety posters** (one peeling off, reading "Remember the 2016 Hull Breach").  
- A **dusty trophy** ("Best Deep-Sea Salvage Team, 2015").  
- A **broken wall clock** (stopped at 3:47—matching the time of a past emergency).  

---  

### **B. Lab Module**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- A **stainless-steel dissection table** (streaked with dried marine samples).  
- A **wall-mounted specimen tank** (cracked glass, leaking slightly).  
- A **microscope station** (one lens missing).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Live shark pup in a containment tank** (needs relocation before it outgrows the space).  
- **Vial of bioluminescent bacteria** (must be kept cold; cooling unit failing).  
- **Sealed mineral sample crate** (marked "VOLATILE—DO NOT TILT").  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- A **centrifuge** (humming loudly, needs oiling).  
- A **whiteboard** (scribbled with half-erased chemical formulas).  
- A **mini-fridge** (door doesn’t fully seal).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Old dive helmets** (used as bookends).  
- **A coffee-stained research journal** (open to a page titled "Vent Shrimp Behavior").  
- **A dented metal lunchbox** (rusted shut).  

---  

### **C. Docking Bay**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- A **partially flooded repair pit** (pump struggling to keep up).  
- A **damaged submersible** ("Deep Scout-7"), one hatch jammed shut.  
- A **crane arm** (rusted gears, groaning under strain).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Leaking fuel drum** (must be moved before it contaminates the bay).  
- **Spare submersible battery** (300kg, requires two agents to lift).  
- **Seawater filtration unit** (clogged with algae).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Dive suit rack** (one suit missing its glove).  
- **Wall-mounted tool panel** (half the tools mislabeled).  
- **A fogged-up porthole** (needs cleaning).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **A faded "Employee of the Month" photo** (peeling at the edges).  
- **A tangled net** (discarded in the corner).  
- **A coffee mug** (floating in the repair pit).  

---  

## **4. Scene Affordances and Embedded Potential**  

### **Collaborative Transportation Affordances:**  
- **Spare submersible battery (300kg, 1.5m x 0.8m x 0.6m)** – Too heavy for one agent; requires coordinated lifting.  
- **Leaking fuel drum (200kg, unstable when tilted)** – Must be carefully carried to avoid spills.  

### **Reasoning and Tool-Use Affordances:**  
- **Attribute-based Reasoning:** Among **five specimen jars**, only one has a **blue label, a hairline crack, and a handwritten "TOXIC" warning**—distinguishing it from the others, some of which are near identical.  
- **Compound (Tool-Use) Reasoning:**  
  - **Problem:** The **jammed submersible hatch** requires a **hydraulic spreader tool**, which is stored in **Maintenance**.  
  - **Solution:** Agents must retrieve the tool while also ensuring the **oxygen recycler** in Maintenance is still functioning.  

### **Dynamic Challenges:**  
- The **leaking overhead pipe** in the Control Room will worsen over time, eventually causing a **short-circuit** if not fixed.  
- The **failing cooling unit** in the Lab risks spoiling critical samples unless repaired.  

This environment is **dense with purpose**—every object has a role, every malfunction demands attention, and every solution requires teamwork. Just like a struggling hockey team rallying for a comeback, the crew of *Shark Reef Outpost* must work together to avoid disaster.
